conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the hemispheres A and B. We will use the principles of static equilibrium and friction.
The line between the two ball centers and the horizontal direction into A makes a 30° angle.
There is friction between hemisphere A and the left wall.
The maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction force.
g is the acceleration of gravity.

premise: Weight of Hemisphere A acts vertically downward and is equal to mg.
conclusion: Weight of Hemisphere A is mg.

premise: Normal force from the wall acts horizontally to the right.
conclusion: Normal force on Hemisphere A is N_A.

premise: Friction force acts vertically upward to prevent sliding.
conclusion: Friction force on Hemisphere A is f_A.

premise: Contact force from Hemisphere B acts along the line joining the centers of the two hemispheres, making a 30° angle with the horizontal.
conclusion: Contact force on Hemisphere A from B is F_{AB}.

premise: Weight of Hemisphere B acts vertically downward and is equal to 2mg.
Normal force from the right wall acts horizontally to the left.
conclusion: Normal force on Hemisphere B is N_B.

premise: Contact force from Hemisphere A acts along the line joining the centers of the two hemispheres, making a 30° angle with the horizontal.
conclusion: Contact force on Hemisphere B from A is F_{AB}.

premise: For Hemisphere A, horizontal forces: N_A = F_{AB} cos(30°).
For Hemisphere A, vertical forces: f_A + F_{AB} sin(30°) = mg.
For Hemisphere B, horizontal forces: N_B = F_{AB} cos(30°).
For Hemisphere B, vertical forces: F_{AB}
